https://cbea.ms/git-commit/ is a great resource for commit messages
Done
Done

Overall, I'd like to get some understanding of what you're trying to accomplish.  You're making changes to the Power schema, which is now deprecated by Redfish, and has moved to the PowerSubsystem schema.  While making edits to what exists is fine, I'd just like to understand what you're trying to accomplish.

PowerSubsystem was intended to replace power, and the defaults just changed.  If this is still being used and developed, we need to have a longer discussion about how we would like it to work.

There are platforms which still use PowerCap interface and power subsystem does not interact with it. My change only touches the code which was hardcoded to look for settings service. Instead it will look for generic service which implements the PowerCap interface

> There are platforms which still use PowerCap interface and power subsystem does not interact with it.

Right, but rather than completely rewriting the implementation in Power, we could just write a new, correct one in PowerSubsystem.  Why wouldn't we do that?  This isn't really fixing a bug, it's adding additional functionality.  Is there something in PowerSubsystem that doesn't work for your use case?

To be clear, I'm in no way saying this patch can't go in once it's correct.  What I'd like is some understanding of why we're continuing to extend capability for schemas that Redfish has abandoned.  If there's something that doesn't work in the "new" schemas, I'd like to understand what that is, so that DMTF can correct it.

Like I said, we just flipped over the defaults to enable the other code path for sensors.  If there's something wrong in that path, it would be good to get that raised at DMTF level, because so far as I'm aware, they think everything is fine in PowerSubsystem.
nit, "ec" please.  Being consistent in naming helps with automation.
Done
nit, should be called "interfaces", as this is a getObject call, it only returns one "object"
it returns the list of objects implementing the power cap interface right? Thats why I used objects
At this level the code is now 3 lambdas deep in non trivial code.  Please correct it to make it normal methods, as the developing guide requires.
Done
Doesn't appear done?  I still see at least a 2 tiered lambda in your new code.
this should be resolved with https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69956
But this is still using the Settings app ?
Done

I see nothing that's checking that this is the power cap for THIS chassis.  as-written, this will allow only one power cap interface on all of OpenBMC, which is disallowed in DBUS_USAGE.md.  Many things have power caps, so we can't just rely on a single one, and we certainly can't expose an API where ANY chassis can be used to set the same power cap without regard for which device it is.  I would expect there to be some association from the chassis to the power interface.


If you only wanted to handle 1, to simplify your patch, you could locate the "main" chassis (which has its own hurdles) and only allow sets on that.
I cleaned up a bunch of the inline lambda stuff.  You might consider stacking your
This doesn't look right.  This REQUIRES that folks implement a power interface.
yes thats the expectation right? This expects an object which implement the power cap interface to update the power cap values

Please don't resolve comments that are still actively being discussed.  It helps maintainers to be able to see what issues are still outstanding.


> yes thats the expectation right?

No.  The expectation is that SOME devices MIGHT implement a power cap.  Certainly not all will.

> This expects an object which implement the power cap interface to update the power cap values

This code is pulling from /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/power_cap in all cases.  There's nothing that's looking up whether the object supports the thing.

Don't construct a callback in the higher scope, then capture it (by copy here, but that's unimportant) into a callback.  Realistically ValueHandler needs to be its own method, but it's already a lambda on master, so I understand how this could have happened.
yeah, it was already done that way. This change does not touch the valuehandler callback
Non trivial lambda.  Please read "anti-patterns" in the openbmc docs.
Done

The power schema is a mess.  Lets start by getting it cleaned up a bit:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69956

That should hopefully make this patchset easier to understand.  As it stands, I'm having a little trouble reading it.
Haven't seen your review on https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69956
sorry lost track of it, let me get to it today
Reviewed the change and tested a modified version of this change on your cleaned-up change and it worked as intended
Thank you.
For the remaining unresolved comments, do we want to address those in this change or a follow up change. As this change is only handling the move from Settings to Generic service part.

> For the remaining unresolved comments, do we want to address those in this change or a follow up change. As this change is only handling the move from Settings to Generic service part.

Lets start by having youre base your patch on the cleanup patch, and we can see how many of them still apply to the new patch.
This looks like a lifetime issue.  I'd be surprised if this code worked as you intended.  PTAL.
right, I was not able to assign ` powerCapService = objects[0].first`. Is there another way of getting the value out of this callback?

The callback happens AFTER the code above has finished, so no, there's not really a way to get the value back out, given how the "order" of things go.  The theory is that we always descend into new code, which in this file is super confusing because even I was confused by this code at first.

Take a look at the cleanup I linked you in the last comment, which breaks out all these lambdas, and it'll probably make more sense.
Sounds good, I will wait till the other cleanup change is in
Please don't wait for anything.  Just stack your patch on top of that one, and help to review it.
Reviewed the change
Unresolving.  this is still a variable lifetime issue.  I'm quite surprised that this worked in your testing.
this exact change is invalid now, I had updated this change to work with https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69956. I have not uploaded that patchset yet.

> I have not uploaded that patchset yet.

That explains why i'm confused that you resolved several comments without uploading a new patch.  Feel free to resolve the comments once you've uploaded the patch.
uploaded a new patch which is rebased on top of your clean up change
please read and understand DBUS_USAGE.md.  Power cap services should be optional, treating a missing power cap as a 500 error doesn't meet that intent.
Done
same here.
Done

How do we know we're getting the power cap for THIS chassis?  Previously we got the global object, so it didn't really matter (all chassis would set the same power cap) but now that we're looking up services, there needs to be a provision for looking up a power cap for a single chassis.

Not really, what if the power cap is for a GPU, and it shows up under redfish/v1/Chassis/main_chassis?

What if the power cap is for the chassis, but shows up under the GPU?

In the original implementation as well we did not check for the chassis right?  The object path was hardcoded to `/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/power_cap`. I tested with original implementation and the chassis was not checked.

To fix it I added a the chassis name as part of the object path. So each object will have to use the chassis in the path. Let me know if this approach is ok or not

> In the original implementation as well we did not check for the chassis right?  The object path was hardcoded to `/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/power_cap`. I tested with original implementation and the chassis was not checked.

Right, but we only ever accessed a single dbus name that we knew was for the whole system.  Once you start looking it up dynamically, there's no way to know.

> 
> To fix it I added a the chassis name as part of the object path. So each object will have to use the chassis in the path. Let me know if this approach is ok or not

Will take a look
This isn't a valid path for a chassis.  I would expect to go to /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory, then look up an assocation back to the Power interface.
not sure I understand, can you point me to an example?
Look for anything using getAssociatedSubTreePaths
I see and for this to work all the services implementing the PowerCap interface need to add association to the Chassis right?
